IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
23-MSP-015273
DUI #23-58-086
Henderson Road @ Bell Street, Henderson, Caroline County, MD
TROOPER T. BENSON #7099
MARYLAND STATE POLICE - EASTON BARRACK
 
 Maryland State Police (MSP) unmarked patrol vehicle I-5 is equipped with a mobile video recording device. Body Worn Camera was operational. Stop recorded.
 
Defendant:
Name: Guidel Nehemias Perez Chilel
Date of Birth: 06/25/1997
MD SDX#: MD-10272925448
Date of Arrest: 04/29/2023
Time of Arrest: 2323
DUI #: 23-58-086 (Easton Barrack)
 
Training & Certificates:
* I am trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).
* I have successfully completed Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) training.
* I have successfully completed Enhanced DUI Enforcement Training through the Maryland State Police SPIDRE Team.
* I have successfully completed Cannabis Impaired Detection Workshop through the Maryland State Police.
 
Narrative:
On Saturday, April 29, 2023, at approximately 2310 hours, I, TFC. Benson #7099, was operating Maryland State Police (MSP) unmarked patrol vehicle I-5 on patrol in the area of Henderson Road and Bell Street in Henderson, Caroline County, MD.

Phase 1 – Vehicle in Motion:
At this time, I observed a black passenger vehicle traveling south on Henderson Road in the area of Bee Tree Road in Henderson, Caroline County, MD. I observed the vehicle swerving back and worth within the southbound lane of Henderson Road, bouncing from the solid, double yellow shoulder line to the solid white edge line and back. As the vehicle passed my location I was able to turn around in an attempt to make additional observations on the vehicle. At this time, the vehicle crossed the solid, double yellow center line with all four (4) tires of the vehicle, entered the opposite lane and began traveling southbound in the northbound lane of Henderson Road. The vehicle continued to drift left across the roadway and the left, driver side tires of the vehicle crossed the solid white edge line of the northbound shoulder of Henderson Road. The vehicle came back across the roadway and re-entered the southbound lane of Henderson Road. Prior to activating my emergency equipment, the vehicle crossed the solid, double yellow center line with both driver’s side tires a second time. At this time, I activated my emergency equipment and initiated a traffic stop on the vehicle. The vehicle, a black Scion TC bearing DE XQ397151, came to a stop on the shoulder of Henderson Road in the area of Bell Street in Henderson, Caroline County, MD. Prior to coming a stop the vehicle almost struck a yellow Planet Aid, Inc. “Clothes & Shoes” drop bin and telephone pole on the property of 114 Henderson Road, Henderson, MD 21640.
 
Phase 2 – Personal Contact:
At this time, I made contact with the driver, identified by his MD drivers license as Guidel Nehemias Perez Chilel, DOB: 06/25/1997, 5/M. As I made contact with Perez Chilel, at the open driver side window, I observed Perez Chilel’s body turned facing the driver side door with his right arm running across the steering wheel, his hands holding onto the door in an attempt to hold his flaccid body in place, and his head sticking out the window. I observed Perez Chilel’s movements to be deliberate, slow, and lethargic as he retrieved his driver’s license. I observed Perez Chilel’s eyes to be red, bloodshot and glassy. Perez Chilel’s eyes appeared heavy with a drastic, visible droop as he looked at me with a thousand-yard stare. As I spoke with Perez Chilel I detected the strong, overwhelming odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his person. While standing at the driver side window, I observed multiple open and empty beer bottles scattered throughout the vehicle.

I asked Perez Chilel where he was going, to which he responded “what happened?” and then pointed aimlessly down Henderson Road in the direction he had been traveling. I then asked Perez Chilel, in Spanish, how many beers he had consume that evening, to which he stated three (3). I then asked Perez Chilel a second time how many beers he had consumed, to which he answered six (6). At this time, I asked Perez Chilel to turn off the vehicle and hand me the keys. I proceeded back to my unmarked patrol vehicle and deactivated my forward, front facing emergency equipment and retrieved my agency issued Preliminary Breath Test (PBT).

At this time, I asked Perez Chilel to exit the vehicle. As Perez Chilel exited the vehicle I observed him to be uneasy and unsteady on his feet. As he walked towards the rear of his vehicle I observed him almost trip over his own feet and fall.

Phase 3 – Pre-Arrest Screening:
Based on my observations, I asked Perez Chilel to submit to a series of Standardized Field Sobriety Tests. Prior to beginning the tests, I asked Perez Chilel if he understood me to which he stated yes.

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) Test:
Prior to beginning the test, I explained the test to Perez Chilel and he advised that he understood. Prior to beginning the test, I held my pen twelve (12) to fifteen (15) inches from Perez Chilel’s nose, slightly above eye level. His pupils were equal in size and showed no resting nystagmus. As I began the test, Perez Chilel  began following the stimulus by turning his head, failing to following instructions and keep his head still and following the pen with his eyes and eyes only. I explained the test to Perez Chilel a second time. I attempted the test a second time and Perez Chilel failed to follow instructions and keep his head still, following the pen with his eyes and eyes only; he moved his head left to right in a “flopping” motion to follow the stimulus.

At this time, I utilized Google Translate to explain the test to Perez Chilel a third time. As I began the test for a third time, Perez Chilel once again failed to follow instructions and keep his head still, following the pen with his eyes and eyes only; he moved his head left to right in a “flopping” motion to follow the stimulus. I utilized Google Translate a second time to explain to Perez Chilel that he needed to keep his head straight and follow the pen with his eyes and eyes only. During the fourth attempt at completing HGN, Perez Chilel continued to not follow instructions and keep his head still, following the pen with his eyes and eyes only; he moved his head left to right in a “flopping” motion to follow the stimulus.
 
A total of zero (0) clues were observed during this test.
 
Walk and Turn (WAT) Test:
Test was not completed.
 
A total of zero (0) clues were observed during this test.
 
One Leg Stand (OLS):
Test was not completed.
 
A total of zero (0) clues were observed during this test.

Preliminary Breath Test (PBT):
Perez Chilel was offered a Preliminary Breath Test roadside. Perez Chilel was instructed to blow air through the straw five (5) separate times, to include two (2) times utilizing Google Translate. All five (5) times Perez Chilel attempted the test he would take a breath in, wrap his lips around the straw, stick in tongue in the hold at the end of the straw, and hold the air in his mouth. He failed to expel any air through the straw and into the PBT on all five (5) attempts. Perez Chilel continued to hold air within his mouth causing him to appear to have “Chipmunk Cheeks.”

Conclusion:
Based on my observations, the results of the Standardized Field Sobriety, along with my training, knowledge, and experience Perez Chilel was placed under arrest at approximately 2323 hours. Perez Chilel was read the Spanish audio version of the “Advice of Rights” form (DR-15) and a Spanish copy was placed on his lap to read along. Perez Chilel agreed to submit to an intoximeter test at approximately 2345 hours. A search incident to arrest was conducted of the interior of the vehicle which revealed:
  • One (1) red Victoria 12 Pack beer box containing three (3) empty Victoria 12 oz. beer bottles, one (1) empty Modelo 12 oz. beer bottle, and one (1) full, unopened Victoria 12 oz. beer bottle. The box was located on the floor immediately behind the front driver seat.
  • One (1) empty Victoria 12 oz. beer bottle located loose on the floor behind the front driver seat.
  • One (1) empty Victoria 12 oz. beer bottle located sitting on the front passenger seat, immediate adjacent to where Perez Chilel was sitting.
  • One (1) empty Modelo 12 oz. beer bottle located on the floor immediately behind the front passenger seat.
  • One (1) full, unopened Victoria 12 oz. beer bottle sitting on the floor next to the center console of the vehicle.
In total, seven (7) empty and two (2) full, unopened 12 oz. beer bottles where located within arms reach of where Perez Chilel was sitting while operating the vehicle. The vehicle was tagged and secured on the shoulder of the roadway. Perez Chilel was transported to the Caroline County Sheriff Office, located at 9305 Double Hills Road, Denton, MD 21629. Upon arrival at CSO, Perez Chilel mouth was checked by CSO Lt. Nepert and the twenty (20) minutes wait time was conducted. The chemical breath test was administered, at approximately 0030, by breath test operator CSO Lt. Nepert #0148. At the time of the test, Perez Chilel refused to approach the intoximeter and provide a breath sample despite the process being explained several times to Perez Chilel in Spanish utilizing Google Translate. Due to this, the intoximeter test timed out, and it was marked as a refusal. It should be noted that Perez Chilel refused to sign the DR-15 and CSO Form #260, both of which are attached to this report. Perez Chilel agreed to sign the DR-15a. Perez Chilel was issued the appropriate paperwork and released from CSO to a sober driver at approximately 0108.
 
CASE CLOSED BY ARREST
 
ALL EVENTS OCCURRED IN CAROLINE COUNTY, MARYLAND
